handlers

Class GetTableStructureHandler

  • java.lang.Object
    • handlers.GetTableStructureHandler
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    io.vertx.core.Handler<io.vertx.ext.web.RoutingContext>

    public class GetTableStructureHandler
extends java.lang.Object
implements io.vertx.core.Handler<io.vertx.ext.web.RoutingContext>
    Handler to manage the routes: - /tables/:schema/:name/structure A request will only be forwarded to this handler if its URL exactly matches this structure. The idea behind this route is to provide details about each column from a table, namely: - Column name - Ordinal Position - If it is Nullable - Data Type - Length - If it is PK

    • Method Detail

      • handle

        public void handle(io.vertx.ext.web.RoutingContext context)
        Central method to the management of requests made to the route this Handlers manages. The general logic is: 1 - Query database for the information requested (passing the eventually present parameter) (queryTable) 2 - Handle the results from said query and populate the response accordingly (handleQueryResults) Sequential execution of the steps is guaranteed via the usage of Futures. The overall logic applied is that the futures never fail because, even if there is some issue in querying the database. This was the design of choice because that would be an issue external to the application. Meaning, that the application's job is to bridge the caller and the database, even if the results are not the desired. That being said, the response sent back to the caller will reflect if the operation went as expected or not. The response body will always contain: 1- In case of success: JsonObject, as body, with the desired results and a Status Code of 200. 2- In case of failure: JsonObject, as body, with the a hint for the reason behind the failure and a Status Code of 500.
        Specified by:
        handle in interface io.vertx.core.Handler<io.vertx.ext.web.RoutingContext>
